messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Tight (Double) Exponential Bounds for Identification Problems: Locating-Dominating Set and Test Cover

Paper Abstract: Abstract We investigate fine-grained algorithmic aspects of identification problems in graphs and set systems, with a focus on Locating-Dominating Set and Test Cover. In the first problem, an input is a graph GğºG on nğ‘›n vertices and an integer kğ‘˜k, and the objective is to decide whether there is a subset Sğ‘†S of kğ‘˜k vertices such that every vertex not in Sğ‘†S is dominated by a unique subset of Sğ‘†S. In the second problem, an input is a set of items Uğ‘ˆU, a collection of subsets â„±â„±\mathcal{F} of Uğ‘ˆU called tests, and an integer kğ‘˜k, and the objective is to select at most kğ‘˜k tests such that for each pair of items, there is a test that contains exactly one of the two items. We prove, among other things, the following three (tight) conditional lower bounds. 1. Locating-Dominating Set does not admit an algorithm running in time 2oâ€‹(k2)â‹…pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(n)â‹…superscript2ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦ğ‘›2^{o(k^{2})}\cdot poly(n), nor a polynomial time kernelization algorithm that reduces the solution size and outputs a kernel with 2oâ€‹(k)superscript2ğ‘œğ‘˜2^{o(k)} vertices, unless the ETH fails. To the best of our knowledge, Locating-Dominating Set is the first problem that admits such an algorithmic lower-bound (with a quadratic function in the exponent) when parameterized by the solution size. The other such results known to us are for structural parameterizations like vertex cover [Agrawal et al., ACM Trans. Comput. Theory 2019; Foucaud et.al., arXiv 2023] or pathwidth [M. Pilipczuk, MFCS 2011; Sau and Souza, Inf. Comput., 2021]. 2. Test Cover does not admit an algorithm running in time 22oâ€‹(k)â‹…pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(|U|+|â„±|)â‹…superscript2superscript2ğ‘œğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦ğ‘ˆâ„±2^{2^{o(k)}}\cdot poly(|U|+|\mathcal{F}|). After Edge Clique Cover [Cygan et al., SIAM J. Comput. 2016] and BiClique Cover [Chandran et al., IPEC 2016], this is the only example that we know of that admits a double exponential lower bound when parameterized by the solution size. 3. Locating-Dominating Set (respectively, Test Cover) parameterized by the treewidth of the input graph (respectively, of the natural auxiliary graph) does not admit an algorithm running in time 22oâ€‹(tw)â‹…pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(n)â‹…superscript2superscript2ğ‘œtwğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦ğ‘›2^{2^{o(\textsf{tw})}}\cdot poly(n) (respectively, 22oâ€‹(tw)â‹…poly(|U|+|â„±|))2^{2^{o(\textsf{tw})}}\cdot poly(|U|+|\mathcal{F}|)). This result augments the small list of NP-Complete problem that admit double exponential lower bounds when parameterized by treewidth [Foucaud et al. arXiv 2023; Chalopin et al. arXiv 2023]. We also present algorithms whose running times match the above lower bounds. We also investigate the incompressibility of these problems, and parameterizations by several other structural graph parameters, such as vertex cover number and feedback edge set number. Our results regarding these parameters answer some open problems from the literature.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Split contraction: The untold story",
        "Paths to trees and cacti",
        "Linear-time algorithms for three domination-based separation problems in block graphs",
        "On the complexity of canonical labelling of strongly regular graphs",
        "On the distance identifying set meta-problem and applications to the complexity of identifying problems on graphs",
        "Partially polynomial kernels for set cover and test cover",
        "Tight approximability results for test set problems in bioinformatics",
        "Induced subsets",
        "Approximation algorithms for the test cover problem",
        "Parameterized algorithms for locating-dominating sets",
        "Non-clashing teaching maps for balls in graphs",
        "On the parameterized complexity of biclique cover and partition",
        "Discriminating codes in bipartite graphs: bounds, extremal cardinalities, complexity",
        "Discriminating codes in (bipartite) planar graphs",
        "On finding optimal discretizations for two attributes",
        "Locating-dominating sets in series-parallel networks",
        "Fully polynomial FPT algorithms for some classes of bounded clique-width graphs",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. I. Recognizable sets of finite graphs",
        "Linear time solvable optimization problems on graphs of bounded clique-width",
        "Parameterizations of test cover with bounded test sizes",
        "Parameterized study of the test cover problem",
        "Known algorithms for edge clique cover are probably optimal",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Graph Theory, 4th Edition, volume 173 of Graduate texts in mathematics",
        "Exact Exponential Algorithms",
        "Kernelization: theory of parameterized preprocessing",
        "Decision and approximation complexity for identifying codes and locating-dominating sets in restricted graph classes",
        "Problems in NP can admit double-exponential lower bounds when parameterized by treewidth and vertex cover",
        "Identification, location-domination and metric dimension on interval and permutation graphs. I. bounds",
        "Identification, location-domination and metric dimension on interval and permutation graphs. II. algorithms and complexity",
        "Twin-cover: Beyond vertex cover in parameterized algorithmics",
        "Computers and Intractability - A guide to NP-completeness",
        "Hardness results and approximation algorithms for identifying codes and locating-dominating codes in graphs",
        "(non-)existence of polynomial kernels for the test cover problem",
        "A synthesis on partition refinement: A useful routine for strings, graphs, boolean matrices and automata",
        "Combinatorics of Finite Sets",
        "On the complexity of k-sat",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Sparsification upper and lower bounds for graph problems and not-all-equal SAT",
        "Parameterized complexity of geodetic set",
        "Treewidth, Computations and Approximations",
        "A single-exponential time 2-approximation algorithm for treewidth",
        "Point line cover: The easy kernel is essentially tight",
        "Algorithmic meta-theorems for restrictions of treewidth",
        "Known algorithms on graphs of bounded treewidth are probably optimal",
        "On minimizing a set of tests",
        "Identifying and locating-dominating codes in (random) geometric networks",
        "Problems parameterized by treewidth tractable in single exponential time: A logical approach",
        "Computational complexity issues in operative diagnosis of graph-based systems",
        "On random generating elements of a finite boolean algebra",
        "Hitting forbidden induced subgraphs on bounded treewidth graphs",
        "Domination and location in acyclic graphs",
        "Dominating and reference sets in a graph",
        "Approximability of identifying codes and locating-dominating codes",
        "A simplified np-complete satisfiability problem",
        "Dynamic programming on tree decompositions using generalised fast subset convolution"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Tight (Double) Exponential Bounds for Identification Problems: Locating-Dominating Set and Test Cover, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
